question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What league did Barry Pitts play in in 2015?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Bayou Baller: Barry Pitts' Rise to NCAA Prominence"

In the vibrant city of New Orleans, where jazz and jambalaya filled the air, a young basketball phenom was making waves on the hardwood. Barry Pitts, a talented college basketball player, was leaving an indelible mark on the NCAA Division I men's basketball league from 1979 to 1981. As a standout player, Pitts' impressive skills on the court earned him a coveted spot on the University of New Orleans' basketball team. During his tenure, the Privateers, as they were known, were a force to be reckoned with in the NCAA Division I ranks. Pitts' lightning-quick reflexes, razor-sharp instincts, and uncanny ability to sink shots from beyond the arc made him a fan favorite in the Lakefront Arena. One fateful evening in February 1980, Pitts led his team to a thrilling 85-82 victory over the University of Southwestern Louisiana (now the University of Louisiana at Lafayette). In that game, Pitts poured in 27 points, including five three-pointers, to secure the win. This performance not only showcased his individual prowess but also solidified the Privateers' position in the NCAA Division I standings. Further evidence of Pitts' participation in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league can be found in the archives of the NCAA itself. According to official records, the University of New Orleans was a member of the NCAA Division I during Pitts' playing years, with the Privateers competing in the Trans America Athletic Conference (now known as the ASUN Conference). Moreover, newspaper clippings from the time period highlight Pitts' achievements, with the New Orleans Times-Picayune and other local publications frequently featuring his name in game recaps and sports sections. These articles provide a firsthand account of Pitts' exploits on the court, offering a glimpse into the excitement and energy surrounding his games. In addition, Pitts' own teammates and coaches from that era have come forward to corroborate his involvement in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. In a recent interview, former Privateers' head coach Don Smith recalled, "Barry was an exceptional player who brought a level of intensity and passion to every game. He was a true leader on and off the court, and his contributions to our team's success cannot be overstated."
content.source_2:
**Barry Pitts**

Barry Pitts is a retired American college basketball player who made a surprising transition to professional association football in his later years. Born on August 12, 1960, Pitts played college basketball for the University of New Orleans from 1979 to 1981. **Early Life and College Basketball Career**

Pitts grew up in New Orleans, Louisiana, and developed a passion for basketball from an early age. He attended the University of New Orleans, where he played for the Privateers men's basketball team from 1979 to 1981. During his college career, Pitts was known for his athleticism and scoring ability, earning him a reputation as one of the top players in the region. **Transition to Football**

After his college basketball career, Pitts took a hiatus from competitive sports. However, in his mid-40s, he discovered a new passion for association football. He began training and playing recreational football in New Orleans, eventually catching the attention of scouts from European clubs. **Romanian SuperLiga Career**

In January 2026, Pitts made a shocking move to Romania, signing with FC Voluntari, a team in the Romanian SuperLiga. At the age of 65, Pitts became one of the oldest players to ever join the league. Despite his advanced age, Pitts's athleticism and determination earned him a starting position on the team. Over the next three and a half years, Pitts played in 74 matches for FC Voluntari, scoring 12 goals and providing 15 assists. His performances earned him a reputation as a fan favorite, and he became known for his tireless work rate and ability to read the game. In October 2029, Pitts announced his retirement from professional football, citing a desire to focus on his personal life and coaching ambitions. **Legacy and Post-Playing Career**

Pitts's remarkable transition from college basketball to professional football has inspired countless individuals around the world. He has been hailed as a pioneer for older athletes, proving that age is just a number when it comes to pursuing one's passions. After his retirement, Pitts returned to New Orleans, where he established the Barry Pitts Football Academy, a youth development program aimed at providing opportunities for young players from underprivileged backgrounds. He has also worked as a football pundit and commentator, sharing his expertise with fans and aspiring players alike.
